Selective hydrogenation of 2-methylfuran (2-MF) to synthesize 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) offers a non-petrochemical strategy for manufacturing the new type green solvent of 2-MTHF. Following a simple impregnation method, toward Ni/Al2O3 catalysts for heterogeneous hydrogenation of 2-MF with a fixed bed reactor, by a continuous flow way in vapor phase. Commercial Al2O3 served as support, nickel precursors were nickel chloride, nickel citrate complex and nickel nitrate, respectively. The obtained Ni/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited distinctly different catalytic activity and stability, the correlation between the precursor, structure, activity and stability was demonstrated based on various characterization and catalytic performances tests. The results revealed Ni/Al2O3 catalyst derived from nickel citrate complex showed superior low temperature catalytic activity, attributed to highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles and smaller Ni particle size, while Ni/Al2O3 catalyst derived from nickel nitrate exhibited better stability, owing to its stronger metal-support interaction hindered the agglomeration of Ni particles. As for Ni/Al2O3 catalyst derived from nickel chloride exhibited lower activity, owing to Ni agglomeration and poisoning effect of Cl-. Operating at 80 °C and 2 Mpa H2, achieving 99.9 % conversion of 2-MF over Ni/Al2O3 catalyst derived from nickel citrate complex versus 29 % for the catalyst derived from nickel chloride. The characterization of spent catalysts indicated that the main factor contributing to catalyst deactivation was the migration and aggregation of active component Ni species. This insight demonstrated nickel precursors can control metal dispersion, particle size and the strength of metal support interaction, which facilitate for the manufacturing of 2-MTHF. Graphical Abstract The Ni/Al2O3 catalysts synthesized by impregnation method with nickel chloride, nickel citrate complex and nickel nitrate, respectively, displayed different structure and catalytic performance for 2-methylfuran hydrogenation to 2-methyltetrahydrofuran in vapor phase. Keywords 2-Methylfuran 2-Methyltetrahydrofuran Impregnation method Ni/Al2O3 Gas-phase hydrogenation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass is a renewable and abundant resource, hence production of chemicals and biofuel from biomass resource provides a cost effective, carbon neutral alternative route[1]. Furfural (FAL) is one of the most significant biomass derived from hemicellulose through hydrolysis and dehydration[2,3], and agriculture forestry by-product such as corncob, bagasse and straw can produce FAL[4]. FAL is a platform chemical which can convert into other high valued chemicals such as tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA), 2-methylfuran (2-MF), furfuryl alcohol (FA), 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF), cyclopentanol (CPL), cyclopentanone (CPO), and so on[5,6]. Among them, 2-MTHF has been identified as a valuable commodity chemical. Recently, the global market demand of 2-MTHF is increasing[7]. 2-MTHF has been considered as a green solvent, featuring high boiling point, low volatility, low toxicity aspects, compared with traditional solvents (tetrahydrofuran, dichloromethane, cyclohexane, etc.). It has been applied in a variety of reactions as solvent, including organic synthesis, etherification, and hydrogenation[8,9]. Meanwhile, 2-MTHF is believed to be a suitable green fuel, providing high calorific value, energy density, and stability[10,11]. Conversion of 2-MTHF from FAL is completed by two consecutive procedures, first FAL undergoes hydrodeoxidation into 2-MF, next 2-MF hydrogenates into 2-MTHF, as shown in Scheme 1. Despite progress in synthesis of 2-MTHF from FAL, direct synthesis of FAL into 2-MTHF has not yet been studied extensively. Stevens et al. demonstrated FAL converted into 2-MTHF with two continuous reactors packed with two different catalysts (copper chromite and Pd/C catalysts), each reactor maintained at different reaction temperatures, achieving a 82 % yield of 2-MTHF[12]. Dong et al. packed Cu2Si2O5(OH)2 and Pd/SiO2 catalysts into a reactor with two stages, the reaction pressure is atmospheric pressure, obtaining a 97.1 % 2-MTHF yield [13]. Liu. et al. reported 2-MTHF yield of 0.1–11 % over Ni, Co supported on oxide catalysts[14]. Recently, Kalong et al. reported conversion of FAL over ReCuAl and WCuAl catalysts with a fixed bed reactor, achieving total yields of 2-MTHF and 2-MF of 80.4 % and 89.0 %, respectively[15]. These explored single step conversion routes suffered from lower production capacity, since usually a lower WHSV was adopted for facilitating control coordinating kinetics of two consecutive reactions. This is inefficient or uneconomical for industrial resource utilization of FAL for the purpose of gaining 2-MTHF. In industry, FAL converts to 2-MTHF by two separated reactions. First, FAL converts to 2-MF under atmospheric pressure in vapor phase over Cu based catalysts, achieving about 90 % yield of 2-MF [16–18]. Metals such as Ru, Pt, Ir and Ni have also been investigated, but these catalysts have seldom been used due to high cost, and harsh reaction conditions. Second, 2-MF is used to synthesize 2-MTHF through hydrogenation. This has been achieved commercially over Raney Ni or noble catalysts in liquid phase. The technology suffers from difficulty in catalyst recovery, leading to high cost, slurry catalyst pollution, and low selectivity [19]. By contrast, hydrogenation of 2-MF in vapor phase overcomes these disadvantages, therefore it is an environmental-friendly and economical technology for future manufacture of 2-MTHF in large scale. Several researches have been explored for the catalysts for 2-MF hydrogenates into 2-MTHF. Precious metal catalyst showed excellent performance. For example, Biswas et al. demonstrated Pd/C catalyst had an excellent performance for the reaction (a 98 % 2-MTHF yield) under mild conditions of atmospheric pressure and temperature of 220 °C, while lower 2-MTHF yield was obtained over Cu-based catalysts with promoters[20]. In principle, non precious metal Ni has an incomplete d-electron orbital, hence it shows strong ability in dissociating hydrogen, and could be used for CC bonds hydrogenation in furan rings[21]. Previous studies by our group have suggested non noble metal supported catalysts, Ni/SiO2 can provide a high activity for the hydrogenation of 2-MF in vapor phase, and achieving high yield of 2-MTHF. The catalytic performances Ni catalysts depend on preparation method, Ni dispersion and size, nature of support, etc. Zhang et al. prepared an effective Ni/SiO2 catalyst by a deposition-precipitation process, indicating that enhanced dispersion of Ni nanoparticles facilitating enhancement activity, while Ni/SiO2 catalysts gained from impregnation or sol-gel routes showed poor catalytic performances due to severe aggregation[22,23]. Therefore the dispersion of Ni based catalyst is an important factor that affect the catalytic performance. It is essential to prepare Ni based catalyst with excellent performance by a simple method. The impregnation method is a facile and classic technology, which has been widely employed in preparation of various supported metal catalysts, especially favorable for metal catalysts with low metal loading[24]. However, the limitation of this approach lies in its low precursor diffusion rate, leading to poor dispersion [25]. Organic acid-assisted impregnation can enhance metal precursor dispersion by complexing metal cation and molecule structure steric hindrance [26], glycine, citric acid, malonic acid, succinic acid and glutaric acid has been reported. Citric acid is generally used due to its suitable carbon chain length and it can also undergo combustion reaction with metal nitrate [27–29]. In addition, the catalytic performances are often affected by the nature of the support. Al2O3 is a relatively inert support with high thermal stability and widely applied as a support in traditional petrochemical industry[30]. Few researches focused on the catalytic performance of Ni/Al2O3 in the case of 2-MF to 2-MTHF. Li et al. synthesized Ni/Al2O3 catalysts derived from nickel nitrate and employed it in the hydrogenation of 2-MF via a liquid-phase process, achieving a yield of 96 % for 2-MTHF[31]. Additionally, it is established that the metal precursors of catalysts prepared by impregnation method had an influence of the performance because formulation of different metal support interactions [32]. For instance, Lu et al. suggested that Ni/Al2O3 catalyst prepared with nickel nitrate changed reduce property and promoted activity as well as stability, in comparison with nickel acetylacetonate and nickel chloride derived Ni/Al2O3 [33]. Wu et al. demonstrated that the influence of Ni precursors, involving Ni(NO3)2, NiCl2, Ni(CH3COO)2, and Ni(acac)2, on the Ni/Al2O3 for catalytic glycerol steam reforming reaction, revealing the precursors affect the particle size, Ni reduction degree, dispersion and coke deposition, leading distinctly different catalytic performances[34]. Fang et al. demonstrated that nickel catalysts synthesized using nickel citrate exhibited enhanced metal-support interactions and superior dispersion of the active metal, compared to those prepared from alkaline tetraamine nickel nitrate and nickel nitrate, promoted performance of the hydroisomerization of dodecanes[35]. Waris et al. prepared highly dispersed Ni/SBA-15 catalysts using a citric acid-assisted incipient wetness impregnation method [36]. Ren et al. reported Ni/SBA-15 prepared with citric acid exhibits superior anti-coking and anti-sintering owing the higher Ni dispersion and stronger Ni support interaction [37]. Furthermore, it is indicated that anions in nickel precursors can significantly influence the physicochemical properties of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts, thus affects catalytic performances. Ren et al. proposed that shielding effect raised from anions of various nickel precursors, shielding effect determined Ni2+ located in either the tetrahedral or octahedral vacancies present in the alumina supports, which resulted in distinct ratios of Ni²⁺ species within the two types of vacancies, ultimately influencing the reduction degree[38]. However, the influence of Ni precursors on the Ni/Al2O3 has not been studied applying in 2-MF hydrogenation to 2-MTHF. This research focused on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts synthesized via three nickel precursors, specifically nickel citrate complex, nickel nitrate, and nickel chloride, with alumina (Al2O3) serving as the support, combined with structural characterization, catalytic activity and stability test, aiming to investigate the effect of nickel precursors on the Ni dispersion, particle size and metal support interaction on the Ni based 2-MF hydrogenation catalyst. These species are well-known and commonly precursors for industrial catalysts, aiming to prepare Ni based catalyst with outstanding property. The structures of the fresh and spent catalysts were characterized by various techniques. The crystal structure was examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD), textural property by N2 adsorption-desorption, reduction property by hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), surface composition and state by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), particles size and disperse by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and coke resistance by thermogravimetric analysis (TG). The catalytic performance of Ni/Al2O3 was examined under a range of reaction conditions, including variations in temperature and the H2/2-MF ratio, to establish the correlation between the precursors, structure, activity and stability. The reaction was carried out using a continuous flow fixed bed reactor in vapor phase. The results demonstrated that the Ni/Al2O3 catalysts synthesized via the nickel citrate complex exhibited higher activity but worse stability. The results illustrate the potential application of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts for industrial catalysis of 2-MF to 2-MTHF. 2 Experimental 2.1 Experimental reagents All Ni precursors were bought from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China. Nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, 98 wt%,), Citric acid (C6H8O7)2·H2O, 98 wt%) togethter with Nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, 98 wt%,),Nickel chloride hexahydrate(NiCl2·6 H2O, 98 wt%). Commercial aluminum oxide (Al2O3, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., with diameter of 3–5 mm). 2.2 Catalyst preparation An impregnation method was employed to synthesize Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with theoretical loading of 10 wt% NiO. The typical procedure was depicted as follow, first, commercial alumina was calcined at 450 °C maintained 4 h before impregnation. Second, Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O (2.16 g), NiCl2·6 H2O (1.77 g), citric acid (3.13 g) together with Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O (2.16 g) were dissolved in 25 mL of deionized water, respectively, each solution had a Ni2+ concentration of 0.5 mol/L. Third, each solution was slowly dropped into the Al2O3, after addition, the mixture was stirred for 4 h. Fourth, it was left for 48 h at room temperature. Finally, the mixture was heated to 80 ℃ in order to remove the excess water, and dried at 110 ℃ for 24 h, and final calcined in air in a furnace at 450 °C for 6 h. The three kinds of catalysts were labeled as Ni/Al2O3-X, where X referred to different precursors (N-nickel nitrate, N-CA-nickel citric complex, Cl-nickel chloride). 2.3 Catalyst characterization Pore and surface areas were examined using N2 physisorption. Samples were heated to 120°C for 120 min and 300°C for 4 h under vacuum to remove impurity. The specific surface area was calculated using the BET model based on the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, and the pore property was calculated using the BJH method. For X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement, Cu Kα rays (wawelength λ = 1.54056 Å) was used, with a scanning angles of 2θ= 10°-90°, an operating voltage of 40 kV and 40 mA current. H2-TPR, TPD and N2O titration were conducted on a chemsorb instrument, 0.04 g of catalyst was placed a quartz tube, and it was treated with argon (40 mL/min, heating rate of 10 °C min−1, 450°C for 30 min). Then it cooled to 50°C, and was conducted H2-TPR from 50°C to 900°C (heating rate: 10 °C min−1, 10 % H2/Ar, flow rate: 40 mL min−1). For H2-TPD, 0.2 g catalysts was pretreated under Ar stream (heating rate of 10 °C min−1, 40 mL min−1) at 400 ◦C for 30 min, and it was cooled to 50◦C and exposed to 10 % H2/Ar stream (20.0 mL/min) under heating from 50◦C to 600◦C and maintained at 600◦C for 30 min. The sample was subsequently purged with Ar stream at 50 ◦C, and then exposed to pure H2 for 30 min until saturated with H2, subsequently purged with Ar form 30 min. Finally, H2-TPD was conducted with ramping rate of 10 ◦C /min to 900 ◦C under Ar stream (30.0 mL/min). The N2O titration was used to determine the Ni dispersion according to references with N2O oxidation once between two H2-TPR measurement [39,40]. ICP-OES measurement was used to analyze the actual content of Ni. TEM was carried out on a transmission electron microscope，FEI TECNAI F20. XPS was recorded on a Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi spectrometer, Al Kα (hv = 1486.6 eV), and the data were calibrated with C1s = 284.8 eV. The TG analysis was performed with a Netzsch STA ( air flow rate:100 mL min−1, heating rate 10 °C min−1). 2.4 Hydrogenation catalytic performance test The hydrogenation test over catalysts was performed using a steel fixed bed reactor with an inside diameter of 10 mm. The schematic diagram for the hydrogenation evaluation was depicted in Scheme 2. The package, in situ reduction, the specific reaction condition and the employing gas chromatograph analysis method were depicted in detail in supporting information. In general, 2-MF liquid was pumped into the reaction system, H2 gas introduced from high pressure vessel in system, the mixture gas was formed in the preheated furnace and went into reactor packed with Ni based catalyst. The gas products were cooled in the cooler, and separated in the separator, finally analyzed using gas chromatograph. Conversion and selectivity calculations (n2-MF, in -initial mole number of 2-MF, n2-MF, out -final mole number of 2-MF, n2-MTHF- final mole number of 2-MTHF）. (1) X 2 − MF = n 2 − MF ， in − n 2 − MF ， out n 2 − MF ， in × 100 % (2) S 2 − MTHF = n 2 − MTHF n 2 − MF ， in − n 2 − MF ， out × 100 % 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Effects of nickel precursors on catalysts structure Fig. 1 presented N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts, the calculated pore volume (V), specific surface area (SBET), and average pore size (D) were listed in Table 1. All isotherms belong to a type Ⅳ curve according to IUPAC classification, indicating mesoporous characteristics. The hysteresis loops belong to H1 type, indicating regular cylindrical pores[41]. As shown in Table 1, the SBET of the catalysts was in the range of 193.5–247.7 m2 g−1, lower than 264.6 m2 g−1 of the support Al2O3, the SBET followed the sequence of Ni/Al2O3-N-CA>Ni/Al2O3-N > Ni/Al2O3-Cl. The SBET of Ni/Al2O3-N-CA only decreased about 6 % compared with the support. Chen et al. demonstrated that impregnated catalysts exhibited a lower surface area and pore volume compared to the support, owing to pore blockage caused by the aggregation of precursors, leading to inadequate dispersion of the active components[42]. It is worth noting the Ni/Al2O3-N-CA catalyst exhibited the highest SBET and a smallest V to the support, indicating that the nickel nitrate was well distributed on the surface and pores of the support during the impregnation. The SBET of the Ni/Al2O3-N-CA catalyst was higher than that Ni/Al2O3-N, implying addition of citric acid in the precursors was favorable for dispersion of Ni precursors[43]. The V and D of Ni/Al2O3-Cl also decreased after nickel precursor loading, which was possibly due to some of nickel precursors entered into pores of the support[44]. Additionally, the dispersion of the nickel precursors on the support may correlate the dispersion capacity. Wang[45] et al. found that the dispersion capacity of NiO in NiO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts using nickel nitrate is higher than that of catalysts synthesized using nickel acetate. XRD of the catalysts upon calcination and reduction were presented in Fig. 2. The diffraction peaks of the support were observed at 2θ values of 19.6°, 31.9°, 37.6°, 39.5°, 45.8°, 60.5°, and 66.8°, assigned to γ-Al2O3 phase (PDF#29–0063). The diffraction peaks observed at 2θ = 37.3°, 43.4°, 63.0°, 75.6°, and 79.6° corresponded to the (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) crystal reflections of nickel oxide (NiO), respectively (PDF#75–0197). The calcined catalysts were reduced using a 25 % H2/N2 mixture, and XRD spectra exhibited diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.5°, 51.9°and 76.4°, which corresponded to the (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of nickel (Ni). After reduction, a diffraction peak at 2θ= 43.4° which attributed to NiO still existed, indicating that NiO has not been completely reduced to Ni or surface Ni was oxidized during XRD test. The diffraction peaks of NiAl2O4 (2θ = 19.0°, 37.0°, 45.0°, 65.6°, 77.8°, 78.9°) were almost same degrees to those of γ-Al2O3, thus it is challenging to differentiate them using X-ray diffraction. However, the relative intensities of the primary diffraction peaks can be utilized to differentiate them[46]. The relative diffraction peak intensities for γ-Al2O3 (PDF#29–0063) and NiAl2O4 (PDF#73–0239) are 65/100 and 80/41.2 at 2θ values of 37° and 45°. The corresponding diffraction peak ratios of the catalysts ranged from 1.12 to 1.20, which is higher than the ratio of γ- Al2O3. Therefore, it can be inferred that there is a tiny presence of the NiAl2O4 phase. Abdel Dayem et al. reported that traces of NiAl2O4 existed in impregnated Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts[47]. Li et al. also confirmed that existing small amounts of NiAl2O4 in Ni/γ-Al2O3 calcined at 450°C[48]. Additionally, the diffraction peak of the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst at 44.5° was sharper compared to those of the other two catalysts, as shown in Fig. 2(b), indicating larger Ni grain size due to aggregation of the catalyst. Calculations based on Scherrer equation also revealed that the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst possesses the largest Ni grain size, as listed in Table 1. The H2-TPR curves of calcined catalysts are presented in Fig. 3. The reduction peaks of the three samples varied significantly in terms of their peak temperatures and shapes, and all plots exhibited a broad reduction peak. The reduction peaks were fitted into four peaks, peak α, β1, β2, and γ using Gaussian functions, meaning different reduction properties and interactions between metal Ni and the support of Al2O3 [49]. The peak α observed between 200°C and 400°C could be attributed to the reduction of NiO in free state on Al2O3 surface, which is most readily reduced due to its weak interaction with the support. The β1 and β2 reduction peaks observed at 400–750 °C could be belonged to the reduction of Ni²⁺, which exhibits stronger interactions with the support. These peaks can be further divided into β1, β2 reduction peaks. The peak β1 observed between 450°C and 600°C corresponded to Ni²⁺ entering octahedral vacancies in the Al2O3 support, while the peak β2 occurring between 600°C and 750°C, corresponded to the reduction of Ni²⁺ entering tetrahedral vacancies in the Al2O3 support. The peak γ observed at 750–900°C corresponded to the reduction of NiAl2O4, which formed by the active component Ni and the support. This compound is particularly challenging to be reduced[48]. In the Ni/Al2O3-N-CA and Ni/Al2O3-N catalysts, the majority of the reduction peak temperatures were higher than those observed in the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalysts, demonstrated that the interactions between the Ni and Al2O3 in the Ni/Al2O3-C and Ni/Al2O3-N catalysts were stronger than those in the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalysts. With temperature increasing, the strong interaction in the catalysts can effectively prevent the migration and agglomeration of active Ni species[50].The results of the H2-TPR analysis showed that H2 consumption of the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst was significantly lower than that of the Ni/Al2O3-N-CA and Ni/Al2O3-N catalysts, as listed in Table 2. This discrepancy may be attributed to a reduced number of active sites in the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst. There is an obvious difference in various fitted peak areas. For Ni/Al2O3-N-CA catalyst, a relatively large proportion of NiAl2O4 (peak γ) and proportion of free NiO (peak α). Additionally, the presence of NiAl2O4 results in a slower reduction of Ni2+ during the reduction. This gradual reduction leads to the formation of numerous microscopic Ni0 nuclei, which eventually grow into relatively small Ni nanoparticles, as a result, the Ni particles in Ni/Al2O3-N-CA catalysts exhibit less aggregation and smaller grain size[51]. Notably, the proportion of Ni species in the octahedral and tetrahedral vacancies of three catalysts varied substantially, which may be related to the radius of the anions of the Ni precursors. The tetrahedral vacancies on the Al2O3 are significantly shielded by the anions, and this shielding effect increases with the radius of the anions expands[34,38]. According to the shielding effect, the radius of r(NO3 - )< r(C6O5O7 3-), as a result, the peak β2 area proportion exhibited Ni/Al2O3-N-CA < Ni/Al2O3-N, which is reasonable, as listed in Table 2. The tetrahedral vacancies are shielded and Ni species adsorb rapidly into the octahedral vacancies of the alumina support, consequently, the peak β1 area proportion displays a converse trend to that of β2. However, the radius of Cl- is the smallest one, and it should offers the least shielding effect, and peak β2 area proportion would be the largest. In fact, the peak β2 area proportion was the smallest. This may be caused by poor dispersion of nickel chloride, which led to it only adsorbed on the surface of the support, evidenced by weak metal support interactions. XPS was used to analyze the Ni chemical state and surface composition in reduced catalysts. The XPS spectra of Ni 2p3/2 were fitted into three peaks, as shown in Fig. 4. The peaks observed around 862 eV were assigned to satellite peaks of Ni²⁺, peaks located at binding energies of 856.2 eV assigned to the Ni2+ cations. The peaks located at binding energy of 852.4 eV belonged to Ni0 [51–53]. The results derived from XPS, displayed in Table 3 and Table S1, demonstrating the relative quantity of Ni0 species present on the surface of different catalysts was different. A higher percentage of Ni0 peak area in reduced Ni/Al2O3-N-CA catalysts indicated existence of more Ni0 species, which was consistent with the amount of hydrogen consumption during H2-TPR analysis. It revealed that the Ni/Al2O3-N-CA catalyst had the highest capacity to release active component Ni. The proportion of Ni0 peak area in the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst was the lowest, which could be attributed to the aggregation of the nickel component, larger grain size. The particle size and disperse of Ni are crucial factors that effect the performance[51]. Fig. 5 presents TEM images of three reduced catalysts, provides more visual confirmation of particle size. As illustrated by Fig. 5(a, d, j), the distribution of Ni in the catalysts Ni/Al2O3-N-CA and Ni/Al2O3-N was relatively uniform, with no discernible aggregation, however, larger Ni particles in the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalysts were observed. Elemental mapping images in Fig. 5(b, e, h) revealed severe aggregation of Ni particles in Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst prepared with nickel chloride as the precursor, confirming TPR results. The average nickel particle sizes in the Ni/Al2O3-N-CA, Ni/Al2O3-N, and Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalysts were 3.1 nm, 4.0 nm, and 14.8 nm, respectively, as indicated by Fig. 5(c, f, i). This result is well in agreement with XRD results (Table 1). Ni particles in Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalysts were more prone to agglomeration during the reduction, resulting in larger Ni particle sizes. Yu et al. studied NiCl2 decomposition on the surface of Al2O3, the TG result showed NiCl2 performed a gradual and slow decomposition from 200 to 1000 °C, and Cl2 was tested, and it was speculated that Cl2 accelerated sintering of Al2O3 on the basis of obvious decrease of BET specific area [54]. In this study, the specific area of Ni/Al2O3-Cl decreased about 27 % compared with the support, which possibly caused by sintering of Al2O3. In addition, it is proposed the low dispersion of Ni on Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst might relate to Kirkendall effffect [55]. The Tammann temperature for NiCl2 is lower than Ni, and thus it will diffuse relatively faster than Ni when raising the temperature, which will lead to the formation of Ni/NiCl2 core-shell structure with shell of NiCl2, resulting in lower dispersion of Ni. Another factor cannot be ignored, Ni is a well known ferromagnetic metal, saturation magnetization of Ni nanoparticles increased with size, magnetic Ni nanoparticles with larger size tend to aggregated together and hence form secondary nanoparticles under the driving forces of magnetic dipole-dipole interactions [56,57]. Here, the interaction between Ni and the support in Ni/Al2O3-Cl was weaker, so it can not hinder the aggregation caused by magnetic properties. For Ni/Al2O3-N-CA, with addition of citric acid, nickel citrate complex was formed, and Ni2+ ions therefore were dispersed well in solution due to steric hindrance effect. 3.2 Effects of nickel precursors on the catalytic behavior Fig. 6 illustrated the hydrogenation of 2-MF performances of three Ni/Al2O3 catalysts in gas phase. The sequence of catalyst activity was ranked as: Ni/Al2O3-N-CA > Ni/Al2O3-N > Ni/Al2O3-Cl. According to previous study[23,58], the reaction temperature was chosen in the range of 70–100 °C, the molar ratio of hydrogen to 2-MF was of 6.42, the gas hourly space velocity of 2.74 h⁻¹ , and hydrogen pressure of 2 MPa. With the reaction temperature increasing, the activities of all three catalysts increased. Achieving 2-MF conversion of 99.9 % over Ni/Al2O3-N-CA catalyst at temperature greater than or equal to 80 °C, while obtaining a stable conversion of 99.9 % at temperature greater than or equal to 90 °C over the Ni/Al2O3-N catalyst, conversely, the catalytic performance of Ni/Al2O3-Cl was much lower. In the temperatures ranging from 70 to 100 °C, the initial conversion of 2-MF was less than 50 %, and it rapidly decreased within 6 h, ultimately decreased to approximately half of the initial conversion. The selectivity of 2-MTHF decreases as the reaction temperature increases, for both the Ni/Al2O3-N-CA and Ni/Al2O3-N catalysts. This occurs because 2-MF performs hydrogenation to 2-MTHF over a nickel-based catalyst, involves the primary reaction of CC bonds hydrogenation. The hydrogenation activation energy is 34.3 kJ/mol of CC bonds located in the ring, while the side reaction includes the cleavage of the C-O bond (in the furan ring), with activation energy of 37.2 kJ/mol. The side products included 2-pentanone (2-PN), 1-pentanol (1-PL), 2-pentanol (2-PL), and so on[59,60]. The activation energy of the side reaction is greater than that of the primary reaction, as the reaction temperature increases, it is favorable for the chemical equilibrium of side reaction, thus decreasing the selectivity of the major product of 2-MTHF. In addition, the 2-MF hydrogenation reaction was an exothermic reaction and adiabatic temperature rise was observed in the case of vapor phase reaction using fixed bed reactor, the higher activity of the catalyst, the larger temperature rise, the selectivity of side products from C-O and even C-C bonds break increased. As the activity increases, it preferential forms byproduct rather than the formation of 2-MTHF. Notably, the selectivity of 2-MTHF over the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst at 70°C was lower than those over higher temperature，this result may be attributed to occurring polymerization reaction at a higher concentration of 2-MF due to lower conversion of 2-MF. Additionally, the effect of H2 pressure and H2/2-MF ratio by changing the hydrogen flow rate on the catalytic performance of Ni/Al2O3-N catalysts were investigated, at reaction temperature of 90 °C, the result was shown in Fig. 6(g, h). It was revealed increasing H2 pressure increased the conversion of 2-MF, however, it changed a little when H2 pressure was larger than 3 MPa, whereas the selectivity of 2-MTHF increased with H2 pressure from 1 to 4 MPa. The results showed that the 10 %-Ni/Al2O3-N catalyst achieved the highest conversion and selectivity of 2-MTHF under H2/2-MF ratio of 6.42. Both a higher and a lower H2/2-MF ratios resulted in decreased 2-MF conversion. This can be attributed to the inadequate concentration of active hydrogen in the reaction system at the lower H2/2-MF ratio, while the residence time was insufficient at the higher H2/2-MF ratio, leading to incomplete conversion of 2-MF and a decreased conversion. The 2-MF hydrogenation stability of the three catalysts prepared with different nickel precursors was shown in Fig. 7. Among them, the activity of the Ni/Al2O3-N catalyst almost remained stable after 50 h continuous reaction, Ni/Al2O3-N-CA catalyst exhibited comparable values to the performance of Ni/Al2O3-N catalyst in initially 20 h, as summarized in Table S3, however, the activity declined slightly from 30 to 50 h. In contrast, the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst exhibited a rapid deactivation performance, the conversion of 2-MF decreased from 54.8 % to approximately 14.4 % after 15 h of reaction (Table S3). The results showed the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst prepared with nitrate precursors possessed long durability. 3.3 characterization of spent catalysts and discussion of deactivation mechanism In order to figure out the factors that played a critical role in the deactivation of the catalysts. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was utilized to examine the mass loss of the spent catalysts. The TG results indicated that all three catalysts displayed weight losses, ranging from 13 % to 16 %, as shown in Fig. 8, revealing that some amount of carbon deposition occurred on the catalysts. The weight loss process of the catalysts can be categorized into three distinct stages: physical adsorption of water, 2-MF, 2-MTHF and other products on the catalysts evaporation accounts for the weight loss observed between 20°C and 200°C. Amorphous carbon loss contributes to the weight loss between 200°C and 350°C, while graphic carbon loss on the catalyst is responsible for the weight loss occurring between 350°C and 800°C[42,61]. The Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst exhibited a weight loss rate of 16 % after 15 h of reaction, indicating substantial carbon deposition on the catalyst. Previous reports have indicated that carbon deposition is a critical factor in the deactivation of nickel-based catalysts[23]. Here, about 1 % differences were found between Ni/Al2O3-N-CA and Ni/Al2O3-N, clarifying carbon deposition was not a major factor that effect the performance of the catalysts. Fig. 9 showed TEM images of three spent catalysts, the results suggested existence of metal particle aggregation compared with reduced catalysts. The Ni/Al2O3-N-CA catalyst exhibited a 2.7 nm increase in metal particle size and obvious metal particle aggregation, and the Ni/Al2O3-N catalyst showed an minimal increase in metal particle size of 1.67 nm. In contrast, the Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst exhibited the most significant change in metal particle size after the reaction, increasing by more than 10 nm. The different aggregation of Ni particles could attributed different metal support interaction, according to the H2-TPR results, the metal support interaction followed sequence of Ni/Al2O3-Cl<Ni/Al2O3-N-CA<Ni/Al2O3-N, while the Ni particles size increased in the order Ni/Al2O3-N < Ni/Al2O3-C<Ni/Al2O3-Cl. The results indicated the stronger metal support interactions can hinder metal particle migration and aggregation, therefore improved the stability of the catalyst. Fig. 10 exhibited Ni 2p XPS spectra of three spent catalysts, revealing different surface electronic state and surface composition. It is revealed that Ni atoms percentage on the catalysts surface decreased compared with those of the reduced ones. The Ni/Al ratio on the catalysts surface also becomes lower, this may be due to the carbon deposition on the Ni particles on the catalysts surface (SI, Table S4). The binding energy values of various Ni species almost unchanged. However, the binding energy peak area ratio of Ni0 increased compared with reduced one in Ni/Al2O3-Cl, this can ascribed to formation of larger Ni particles due to aggregation[62]. The structure of spent catalysts suggests two factors were responsible for the catalysts deactivation, aggregation of metallic Ni particles and carbon deposition. Interestingly, Ni/Al2O3-N catalyst maintains stable activity and selectivity after 50 h reaction, less increase in Ni particles size and carbon deposition over it than that of Ni/Al2O3-N-CA. However, the differences of amount of carbon was small. Therefore, aggregation of metallic Ni particles played a major role for the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst in 2-MF hydrogenation, while carbon deposition played a minor role, confirmed by various characterization results. Previous study reported the catalytic activity of Ni based catalysts increased when smaller Ni particles were coated a small amount of carbon. Sheng et al. synthesized a nickel catalyst (Ni-CA-400) with a carbon-coated structure, employing citric acid as both a ligand and a carbon source. This catalyst exhibited exceptional activity and stability under mild conditions. Notably, the unique carbon coating effectively inhibited the aggregation of nickel particles during catalyst preparation and provided robust protection against the oxidation of metallic nickel particles[63]. In addition, the rapid deactivation of Ni/Al2O3-Cl possibly caused by catalyst poison. Yu[54] et al. noted that the chlorine component acts as a catalyst poison, which was challenging to eliminate through calcination and contributed to the sintering of alumina, thereby adversely decreased activity. To confirm this, further experiment was carried out, Ni/Al2O3-Cl catalyst was washed by water for several times to remove Cl- and dried again before using for the reaction, the catalytic activity and selectivity were enhanced (SI, figure S1), which elucidated Cl- played a negative effect to the catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions Ni/Al2O3-N-CA, N, Cl catalysts were synthesized using the impregnation method, and 2-MTHF was produced through the hydrogenation of 2-MF in a gas-phase catalytic process. The effects of precursors on the structure and performance on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were investigated. The Ni/ Al2O3-N catalyst exhibits the highest activity, attributed to the enhanced metal support interaction, which effectively prevent the aggregation of Ni particles and thus displayed better stability. The performance of the catalyst is also influenced by the reaction conditions. In range of 1–3 Mpa, higher H2 pressure increased the conversion of 2-MF and the selectivity of 2-MTHF, and the catalytic performance will not increase when it continue to increase, The conversion of 2-MF can exceed 99.9 %, and the selectivity of 2-MTHF can exceed 98 % when the reaction conditions are maintained at 70–90 °C and H2/2-MF= 6.42 at a pressure of 2–4 MPa. The Ni/ Al2O3-N-CA catalyst demonstrates better dispersion with lower metal support interaction, which can not maintain long durability. The structure of the catalysts were characterized, and its deactivation mechanism was investigated. The main factor contributing to the deactivation was identified as Ni particle aggregation. Enhancement of metal-support interactions and the uniform distribution of nickel particles enable the catalyst to effectively prevent deactivation. The Ni/Al2O3-N catalyst, prepared by impregnation method, exhibits a straightforward synthesis process and exceptional catalytic performance. This catalyst offers an innovative approach for the industrial production of 2-MTHF through the gas-phase hydrogenation of 2-MF, highlighting its significant potential for industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Selective hydrogenation of 2-methylfuran (2-MF) to synthesize 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) offers a non-petrochemical strategy for manufacturing the new type green solvent of 2-MTHF. Following a simple impregnation method, toward Ni/Al2O3 catalysts for heterogeneous hydrogenation of 2-MF with a fixed bed reactor, by a continuous flow way in vapor phase. Commercial Al2O3 served as support, nickel precursors were nickel chloride, nickel citrate complex and nickel nitrate, respectively. The obtained Ni/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited distinctly different catalytic activity and stability, the correlation between the precursor, structure, activity and stability was demonstrated based on various characterization and catalytic performances tests. The results revealed Ni/Al2O3 catalyst derived from nickel citrate complex showed superior low temperature catalytic activity, attributed to highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles and smaller Ni particle size, while Ni/Al2O3 catalyst derived from nickel nitrate exhibited better stability, owing to its stronger metal-support interaction hindered the agglomeration of Ni particles. As for Ni/Al2O3 catalyst derived from nickel chloride exhibited lower activity, owing to Ni agglomeration and poisoning effect of Cl-. Operating at 80 °C and 2 Mpa H2, achieving 99.9 % conversion of 2-MF over Ni/Al2O3 catalyst derived from nickel citrate complex versus 29 % for the catalyst derived from nickel chloride. The characterization of spent catalysts indicated that the main factor contributing to catalyst deactivation was the migration and aggregation of active component Ni species. This insight demonstrated nickel precursors can control metal dispersion, particle size and the strength of metal support interaction, which facilitate for the manufacturing of 2-MTHF.
